Weekly Hours Signal

Weekly hours signal: tracking average working hours as an indicator of labour demand.

As of 2025-12-10

Gemini Summary

State of the Market Summary:

  • Overall labor demand, indicated by weekly hours, currently shows a NEUTRAL regime through September 2025.
  • The Hours Level Composite z-score ranged from -0.67 to 0.67, implying no extreme positioning.
  • Manufacturing hours z-score reached 1.35 in July 2025, suggesting moderate strength in this sector.
  • Total private hours z-score remained at 0.00 during this period, indicating stability.

Technical Summary:

  • The Hours Level Composite z-score did not breach the "HOT" (>+0.75) or "COOL" (<-0.75) thresholds [Source: weekly_hours_methodology].
  • This lack of extreme z-scores suggests no significant stretch or crowding in overall weekly hours.
  • There is no clear signal for squeeze or unwind risk based on current composite levels.
  • The neutral regime indicates stable, non-extreme labor demand momentum across the period [Source: weekly_hours_methodology].

References:

  • Weekly Hours (CES) Data: Latest observation 2025-09-01.
  • The `Weekly_Hours_Regime` and `Hours_Level_Composite_z` most influenced these conclusions.
  • Public datasets to improve future analysis: Labor Market Tightness Signal [Source: labor_market_tightness_methodology].
  • Public datasets to improve future analysis: Economic Cycle Proxies Flow Momentum [Source: Economic_Cycle_Proxies_Flow_Momentum.html].
Self-healing: - High-Value Inputs to Add: Provide actual payroll growth data to complement weekly hours analysis. - High-Value Inputs to Add: Include specific order-book signals to assess future demand expectations. - High-Value Inputs to Add: Add Underemployment Risk Signal for deeper labor market slack insight [Source: underemployment_risk_methodology]. - Weaknesses in Provided Inputs: The data consistently showed a "NEUTRAL" regime; provide data exhibiting "HOT" or "COOL" regimes for more robust analysis of extremes.
